items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> The significant abrasive wear of sprocket drum teeth and seats bottoms is observed during the exploitation of longwall scraper conveyors. For this reason, it is important to determine friction work in sliding conditions of the horizontal link on the tooth seat bottom and on the tooth flank and friction work in the joint of links in the context of such nodes’ abrasive wear. The different construction variants of sprocket drums can be compared by determining friction work in the sliding positions of the horizontal link on the drum. The determination of the losses of the power transmitted is a requisite condition in such situation for determining the efficiency values of chain meshing. The friction work of the friction couple of a sprocket drum - link chain consists of friction work of the horizontal link in the places where it contacts with the seat bottom A<jats:sub>g</jats:sub> and the tooth flank A<jats:sub>f</jats:sub> and friction work in the joints of a horizontal link in the contact place with vertical links: in the front joint A<jats:sub>p</jats:sub> and the rear joint A<jats:sub>t</jats:sub>. The article presents dependencies enabling to determine the value of such work for specific geometric relations between the chain and the drum and different friction conditions. The curves of relative friction work and the values of total friction work on the seat bottom, on the tooth flank and in a front and rear joint of links are presented for examples of friction conditions.</jats:p>
title: Determination of the Friction Work of a Link Chain Interworking with a Sprocket Drum / Wyznaczenie Pracy Tarcia Łańcucha Ogniwowego We Współdziałaniu Z Bębnem Łańcuchowym
subject: Geotechnical Engineering and Engineering Geology
Geochemistry and Petrology

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>Seats in conventional sprocket drums are symmetrical. Due to the set general direction of sprocket drum revolutions resulting from the direction of rock transport, the wear of the seat bottoms and teeth flanks may be reduced by introducing the asymmetry of the profile of the sprocket drum seats. The proposed modification of sprocket drum seats’ profile consists of inclining the seat bottom towards the expected direction of the basic drum revolutions.</jats:p>
<jats:p>The work compares the loads on the seats and teeth of a conventional drum with its profile conforming to the standard to a modified drum with an asymmetric profile of seats. For the general direction of sprocket drum revolutions, the maximum values of all forces are higher for a standard drum than for a modified drum. The profile asymmetry substantially shortens the friction path of the horizontal link front torus on the seat bottom and relative total friction work on the seat bottom and lessens the occurrence probability of the slide of the horizontal link rear torus on the tooth flank. The modification of the profile causes also the asymmetric wear of link joints. The total relative friction work is considerably reduced in the front joint as compared to a conventional drum, and the total relative friction work in the rear joint is increasing at the same time.</jats:p>
title: Comparison of Conventional Sprocket Drum and Sprocket Drum with Modified Design

items.abstract: <jats:p>The title zinc alkoxide, bis(μ-2-ethoxyphenolato)-κ<jats:sup>3</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>:<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>;κ<jats:sup>3</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>:<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>-bis[(2-ethoxyphenolato-κ<jats:sup>2</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>)(pyridine-κ<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>)zinc(II)] toluene hemisolvate, [Zn<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>9</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>N)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>]·0.5C<jats:sub>7</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>, crystallizes with two independent complex molecules located on inversion centres and one independent toluene solvent molecule disordered about an inversion centre. The Zn<jats:sup>II</jats:sup>atoms are six-coordinated in distorted octahedral geometries with O<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>N donor sets. The Zn<jats:sup>II</jats:sup>ions and bridging alkoxide groups are arranged in a diamond Zn<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>core structure. The guetholate (2-ethoxyphenolate) ligands adopt two different coordination modes,<jats:italic>viz.</jats:italic>peripheral chelating and μ<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-bridging. Preliminary investigations of the catalytic activity of the compound in the ring-opening polymerization of L-lactide demonstrate rapid and efficient generation of polylactide.</jats:p>
title: A dinuclear zinc complex containing a diamond-core geometry: [Zn2(μ2-GueO)2(GueO)2(py)2]·0.5(toluene) (GueOH is guethol)

items.abstract: <jats:p>The zinc alkoxide molecules in di-μ<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>-ethanolato-diethyltetrakis(μ<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-2-methyl-4-oxo-4<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>-pyran-3-olato-κ<jats:sup>3</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>3</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>4</jats:sup>:<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>3</jats:sup>)tetrazinc(II), [Zn<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>O)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>], (I), and bis(μ<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>-2-ethoxyphenolato-κ<jats:sup>4</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>:<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>:<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>)bis(μ<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-2-ethoxyphenolato-κ<jats:sup>3</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>:<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>1</jats:sup>)bis(μ<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-2-methyl-4-oxo-4<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>-pyran-3-olato-κ<jats:sup>3</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>3</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>4</jats:sup>:<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>3</jats:sup>)bis(2-methyl-4-oxo-4<jats:italic>H</jats:italic>-pyran-3-olato-κ<jats:sup>2</jats:sup><jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>3</jats:sup>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic><jats:sup>4</jats:sup>)tetrazinc(II) toluene disolvate, [Zn<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>9</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>]·2C<jats:sub>7</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>, (II), lie on crystallographic centres of inversion. The asymmetric units of (I) and (II) contain half of the tetrameric unit and additionally one molecule of toluene for (II). The Zn<jats:sup>II</jats:sup>atoms are four- and six-coordinated in distorted tetrahedral and octahedral geometries for (I), and six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral environment for (II). The Zn<jats:sup>II</jats:sup>atoms in both compounds are arranged in a defect dicubane Zn<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>core structure composed of two EtZnO<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>tetrahedra and ZnO<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>octahedra for (I), and of four ZnO<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>octahedra for (II), sharing common corners. The maltolate ligands exist mostly in a μ<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-bridging mode, while the guetholate ligands prefer a higher coordination mode and act as μ<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>- and μ<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-bridges.</jats:p>
title: Two tetranuclear zinc clusters, [Zn4(μ3-OEt)2(μ2-MalO)4Et2] and [Zn4(μ3-GueO)2(μ2-GueO)2(μ2-MalO)2(MalO)2]·2C7H8, containing defective dicubane core geometries (MalOH is maltol and GueOH is guethol)
